results_summary: The study found that anacaulase-bcdb is a safe, non-surgical eschar removal agent with advantages over surgical excision, including faster eschar removal, fewer operations, reduced autografting, shorter hospital stays, less blood loss, and improved cosmetic outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with deep partial-thickness and full-thickness burns.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bromelain-based enzymatic debridement as an alternative to surgical debridement for deep second and third-degree burns.
results_summary: The study found that bromelain-based enzymatic debridement is effective in selectively removing eschar in deep burns, reducing the need for autologous skin grafting compared to surgical standard of care. Off-label use of NexoBrid (a bromelain-based product) was also noted as promising.
population_specificity: Patients with deep second and third-degree burns.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate natural products, including Bromelain, for their potential antiviral, anti-inflammatory, and immunomodulatory properties in COVID-19 management.
results_summary: Bromelain was included in a quadruple treatment (zinc, quercetin, bromelain, and vitamin C) suggested for COVID-19 management, but specific efficacy data for Bromelain alone were not detailed in the abstract. The study highlighted synergistic effects of combined treatments.
population_specificity: Not specified (general COVID-19 context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of proteolytic enzymes, including bromelain, as exfoliants in cosmetic formulations and their effects on skin characteristics.
results_summary: The study found that bromelain can effectively exfoliate the skin and improve desired skin characteristics, though few clinical trials were identified. Factors like pH, temperature, and enzyme stabilization were noted as important to prevent irritation and maintain activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence on the efficacy of bromelain and other nutraceuticals in alleviating NAFLD.
results_summary: The abstract mentions bromelain as one of the studied substances for NAFLD, but specific results for bromelain are not detailed. The review highlights the potential of natural products, including bromelain, in addressing NAFLD.
population_specificity: Patients with NAFLD and animal models (as inferred from the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review clinical studies on the effects of medicinal plants, including bromelain, in improving wound healing parameters in patients with diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).
results_summary: Bromelain, used as an enzymatic debridement agent, showed significant improvements in wound healing parameters such as ulcer width, depth, epithelialization, and wound closure in DFU patients. The review highlighted its potential as an adjuvant therapy to conventional wound care.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of EscharEx, a bromelain-based enzymatic debridement agent, in treating chronic wounds.
results_summary: EscharEx achieved significantly higher complete debridement rates (55% vs. 29%) compared to the gel vehicle, but no significant differences were observed in wound closure rates or time to closure. The treatment demonstrated a favorable safety profile with no significant safety issues.
population_specificity: 73 patients with lower extremity ulcers of diabetic, venous insufficiency, post-surgical, or traumatic etiology.
effective_dosage: Topical treatment for up to 10 daily 4-hour applications.
study_duration: Up to 10 days of treatment, followed by 6 months of follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of bromelain, among other natural compounds, as a therapeutic option for treating lymphomas by examining its effects on cell proliferation, apoptosis, and cell cycle regulation.
results_summary: The study found that bromelain, along with other natural compounds, exhibited anti-lymphoma activities by regulating signaling pathways related to cell proliferation, apoptosis, and cell cycle in both in-vivo and in-vitro studies, suggesting its potential as a therapeutic option.
population_specificity: Not specified (general lymphoma context, no specific human or animal population detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review existing evidence on the role of Bromelain and other proteolytic enzymes in cancer treatment, focusing on their potential to reduce side-effects and improve therapy outcomes.
results_summary: The study found insufficient evidence to attribute positive effects to Bromelain in terms of better tolerability or improved efficacy of cancer therapies. Enzyme therapy was generally well tolerated, with side-effects mainly limited to gastrointestinal complaints like diarrhea or meteorism.
population_specificity: Patients with various cancers, including gastrointestinal, gynecologic, head and neck, lung cancer, and hematological malignancies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a bromelain enzyme pre-rinse could enhance plaque removal in subjects with fixed orthodontic appliances when used alongside standard dental cleaning methods.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in plaque removal between bromelain and placebo pre-rinses. Significant plaque reduction occurred after brushing and Waterpik use in both groups, but bromelain did not provide additional benefits.
population_specificity: 43 orthodontic subjects aged 10-25 with fixed appliances.
study_duration: Crossover design with two visits (duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate bromelain's potential as a treatment for COVID-19 symptoms, focusing on its anti-inflammatory and anticoagulatory properties.
results_summary: The study suggests bromelain may inhibit or prevent COVID-19 symptoms due to its anti-inflammatory and anticoagulatory effects, supported by experimental and clinical evidence.
population_specificity: Not specified (general COVID-19 context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a combined anthocyanins and bromelain supplement (BE) on endothelial function, blood pressure, total antioxidant capacity, oxygen utility capacity, and fatigability in healthy adults.
results_summary: The BE group showed significantly improved endothelial function (increased FMD), reduced systolic blood pressure, enhanced oxygen utility capacity, and increased total antioxidant capacity compared to placebo. No significant differences were observed for resting heart rate, diastolic blood pressure, or fatigability.
population_specificity: Healthy adults (n=18, age 24±4 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Bromelain in enzymatic debridement of burn wounds as an adjunct therapy to reduce surgical debridement sessions or graft area.
results_summary: Bromelain was found to potentially help reduce the need for surgical debridement sessions or the area requiring grafting, though more studies with larger sample sizes are needed to confirm its exact role. The study noted that enzymatic debridement, including Bromelain, could be effective but surgical excision remains the standard of care.
population_specificity: Patients with burn wounds, particularly those requiring debridement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update consensus guidelines for the use of Bromelain-based Enzymatic Debridement (ED) in burn care, focusing on indications, application, and post-interventional management.
results_summary: The updated guidelines reflect clinical experience from 1,232 patient cases, with high consensus (97.7%) on 43 statements. The study introduced a classification for timing of ED application and provided detailed recommendations to improve patient care and prevent pitfalls.
population_specificity: Patients with mid-to deep dermal burns, treated by plastic surgeons and burn care specialists across twelve European centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence for Bromelain's efficacy and safety as an alternative therapy for sinusitis and rhinitis.
results_summary: Bromelain received a low to moderate-high GRADE rating, indicating some evidence of efficacy for treating sinusitis and rhinitis, though comparisons to traditional therapies were lacking.
population_specificity: Patients with sinusitis and rhinitis (allergic rhinitis was the most common condition studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review how specific nutrients, including Bromelain, influence wound healing through epigenetic signals.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Bromelain's effects, only mentioning its inclusion among nutrients targeting wound healing processes.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop near-infrared (NIR) light-activatable protherapeutic agents, specifically semiconducting polymer nanomaterials (SPNs), for cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study summarized SPNs as NIR photoactivatable protherapeutic agents capable of converting NIR light into heat or singlet oxygen for cancer therapy, addressing limitations of ultraviolet-visible light-responsive agents.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on in vitro/in vivo applications of SPNs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of bromelain and papain compared to standard aceclofenac treatment in reducing pain and improving quality of life in patients with lumbar spine osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The enzyme supplement group showed significant reductions in pain scores (VAS and ODI), improved liver/kidney enzyme levels, and enhanced quality of life without adverse changes in BMI or vital signs, suggesting prolonged beneficial effects compared to standard treatment.
population_specificity: 40 men and women with lumbar spine osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 250 mg b.i.d (twice daily) of enzyme supplements.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and preliminary efficacy of Bromelain (Brom) combined with Acetylcysteine (Ac) for treating mucinous peritoneal tumours.
results_summary: The study found that BromAc had a manageable safety profile with common but mostly mild adverse events, and demonstrated considerable mucolytic activity, with an objective response in 73.2% of treated sites.
population_specificity: 20 patients with mucinous tumours.
effective_dosage: Brom 20-60 mg and Ac 1.5-2 g in 5% glucose, administered via drain.
study_duration: Treatment and assessment occurred over 24 hours, with repeat doses in most patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Broser® (containing bromelain, escin, and selenium) for its anti-inflammatory activity in patients with ORL disorders.
results_summary: The study suggested that Broser® could exert safe and effective anti-inflammatory activity, but specific results regarding bromelain's effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients treated in 84 Italian ORL centers.
effective_dosage: Bromelain 100 mg (as part of Broser® formulation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of bromelain on health outcomes, including pain reduction and quality of life, in patients undergoing third molar surgery.
results_summary: Bromelain showed large effect sizes in improving physical appearance, social isolation, and sleep quality during the first postoperative week, as well as reducing pain intensity within 24 hours and 7 days after surgery. However, it was not effective in reducing trismus or facial swelling.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing third molar surgery

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical evidence of bromelain in reducing inflammatory parameters (pain, edema, and trismus) following lower third molar surgeries.
results_summary: Bromelain showed statistically significant reductions in pain, edema, and trismus after lower third molar surgeries, though further high-quality studies are needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing lower third molar surgeries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bromelain is effective for controlling pain and inflammation associated with third molar surgery.
results_summary: Bromelain was effective at reducing postoperative pain at 48-72 hours after surgery but did not significantly affect edema or trismus compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing third molar surgery (252 patients across five studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a phytotherapeutic drug containing bromelain, baicalin, and escin against ibuprofen and placebo in managing postoperative pain and discomfort after mandibular third molar surgery.
results_summary: The phytotherapeutic drug (including bromelain) significantly reduced postoperative pain at 12h, 24h, and 48h compared to ibuprofen and placebo, with similar effects on swelling and trismus.
population_specificity: 82 patients undergoing surgical removal of impacted mandibular third molars.
effective_dosage: 50 mg bromelain (as part of a combination), administered twice daily.

study_goal: To assess whether bromelain combined with tamsulosin improves spontaneous stone passage rates compared to tamsulosin alone in patients with distal ureteral stones.
results_summary: Bromelain plus tamsulosin significantly increased spontaneous stone passage rates (87.7% vs. 75.4%) compared to tamsulosin alone, particularly for larger stones (>5 mm). No bromelain-related side effects were reported.
population_specificity: 114 patients with symptomatic distal ureteral stones (4-10 mm).
study_duration: Up to 30 days or until stone passage/intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bromelain in combination with other supplements (NAC and ALA) for the prevention and treatment of endometriosis.
results_summary: The study found that bromelain, in association with NAC and ALA, is used for the prevention and treatment of endometriosis, suggesting potential benefits in managing this condition.
population_specificity: Women with gynecological and obstetrical conditions, including endometriosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of a supplement containing bromelain, N-acetyl cysteine, and alpha lipoic acid on endometriosis-associated pelvic pain.
results_summary: The study found that after 6 months of treatment, the percentage of patients with pain intensity >4 on the VAS decreased significantly from 92.7% to 82.7%, indicating a reduction in pain. Patients also required fewer rescue analgesics.
population_specificity: Women with endometriosis-associated pelvic pain (mean age 34.6 ± 7.2 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical evidence supporting the use of Bromelain as an alternative therapy for chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS).
results_summary: The study found that Bromelain additives to saline lavage in CRS are supported by clinical evidence, though higher levels of evidence from large, well-designed trials are needed for stronger recommendations.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review Bromelain's immunomodulatory and anticancer mechanisms, focusing on its effects on tumor growth, proliferation, and immune response activation.
results_summary: The abstract suggests Bromelain exhibits anticancer activity through anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, apoptosis induction, anti-angiogenesis, and anti-metastasis effects, alongside potential immunostimulatory properties that may aid in tumor recognition and destruction.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of enzymatic debridement with bromelain (EDNX) versus traditional surgical debridement (TSD) for treating deep dermal and full-thickness hand burns.
results_summary: EDNX significantly reduced time to complete debridement, treatments needed for debridement, and time to complete healing, while also improving burn depth evaluation and reducing the need for autografting. Scar quality after 3 months was nearly equivalent between groups, with only heightened local redness in the EDNX group.
population_specificity: 40 patients aged 18-76 years with deep dermal burns of the hand.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency, handling, and healing potential of enzymatic debridement with bromelain (EDNX) in treating deeply burned hands compared to traditional surgical debridement.
results_summary: EDNX was effective in 90% of treatments, though wound bed evaluation was challenging. Post-treatment, burn surface area was often overestimated, but the process was simplified, reducing costs and enabling bedside treatment under plexus anesthesia.
population_specificity: 20 patients with deeply burned hands.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Bromelain-based enzymatic debridement versus surgical debridement in treating deep dermal facial burns, focusing on wound closure time, scar quality, and tissue preservation.
results_summary: Enzymatic debridement with Bromelain significantly reduced wound closure time, required fewer procedures, and resulted in superior scar quality compared to surgical debridement after 12 months. It also reduced the need for autografting and preserved more viable dermis than initially estimated.
population_specificity: 26 subjects aged 18-78 years with deep dermal or deeper facial burns.
study_duration: Follow-up period of more than 12 months

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of oral bromelain on postoperative discomfort after mandibular third molar surgery, comparing its efficacy alone and in combination with dexamethasone.
results_summary: Bromelain alone showed moderate anti-inflammatory efficacy, reducing swelling but not significantly compared to no treatment. Combined use with dexamethasone yielded the best results, significantly reducing swelling and analgesic use post-surgery.
population_specificity: 84 patients requiring surgical removal of a single mandibular impacted third molar under local anesthesia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and tolerability of oral enzyme treatments, including trypsin:chymotrypsin (TC), in reducing inflammation and improving wound healing after orthopedic surgery.
results_summary: TC showed significantly better reduction in erythema, local irritation, wound discharge, edema, induration, and pain compared to other treatments, with 88-92% of patients reporting good to excellent efficacy and tolerability.
population_specificity: Patients recovering from orthopedic surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether adding bromelain (in combination with other extracts) to levofloxacin improved clinical efficacy and safety in treating chronic bacterial prostatitis (CBP).
results_summary: The combination including bromelain significantly improved symptom scores (NIH-CPSI, IPSS) and reduced recurrence rates compared to levofloxacin alone, with no reported side effects. Microbiological cure rates were similar between groups.
population_specificity: Men with clinical and instrumental diagnosis of chronic bacterial prostatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of a 16-week bromelain treatment compared to diclofenac in patients with mild-to-moderate knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Bromelain showed comparable efficacy to diclofenac after 4 weeks, with no significant differences in WOMAC or SF-36 scores. By week 16, bromelain improved WOMAC scores, pain, stiffness, function, and SF-36 physical component, while reducing oxidative stress markers.
population_specificity: Patients with mild-to-moderate knee osteoarthritis (n=40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal dosage of bromelain for reducing postoperative edema and inflammatory reactions after wisdom teeth extraction by comparing 1000 FIP, 3000 FIP, and 4500 FIP doses.
results_summary: The study found no superiority of higher bromelain doses (3000 FIP and 4500 FIP) over the standard 1000 FIP dose, but pooled bromelain treatments showed a clear trend favoring bromelain over placebo for reducing swelling, pain, and other postoperative symptoms. Adverse events were not more frequent with bromelain than placebo.
population_specificity: 68 patients who underwent wisdom teeth extraction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if bromelain could reduce plasma fibrinogen and other cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors in diabetic patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in fibrinogen reduction or other CVD risk factors between the bromelain and placebo groups, suggesting bromelain had no beneficial effect on these outcomes.
population_specificity: 68 Chinese diabetic patients (32 males, 36 females; Han origin; mean age 61.26 years) with at least one CVD risk factor.
effective_dosage: 1,050 mg/day (350 mg × 3 capsules: two after breakfast, one after dinner).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile and summarize existing data on bromelain, focusing on its physicochemical properties, purification techniques, and therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The study highlights bromelain's anti-inflammatory, anti-cancer, and apoptosis-inducing properties, along with various purification methods and its growing market relevance.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anticancer effects of bromelain on intra- and extrahepatic human cholangiocarcinoma (CC) cell lines, focusing on proliferation, migration, invasion, and apoptosis.
results_summary: Bromelain reduced proliferation, invasion, and migration of CC cells, inhibited NFκB/AMPK signaling and downstream proteins, downregulated MMP9 and epithelial-mesenchymal-transition markers, and induced apoptosis. Bromelain was more effective than papain in inhibiting CC.
population_specificity: Human cholangiocarcinoma (CC) cell lines (intra- and extrahepatic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of enzymatic (papain and bromelain) versus abrasive components in whitening toothpaste for removing extrinsic stains.
results_summary: Both enzymatic and abrasive toothpastes significantly reduced extrinsic stains, with the enzymatic paste showing slightly better results. The reductions were statistically significant at 1 and 2 months.
population_specificity: 90 subjects aged 18-40 years.
study_duration: 1 month for stain removal, 2 months for stain prevention efficacy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of bromelain in reducing postoperative pain and swelling following impacted third molar surgery.
results_summary: Bromelain significantly reduced postoperative pain, edema, and erythema compared to the control group, with slightly lower analgesic consumption. Only one adverse event was recorded in the control group.
population_specificity: 80 patients undergoing impacted third molar surgery at the Maxillofacial Surgery Unit of the Istituto Stomatologico Italiano, Milan, Italy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether plant-derived VLP vaccines, including those using bromelain as a target antigen, elicited allergic or hypersensitivity responses in subjects.
results_summary: No allergic/hypersensitivity symptoms were observed in subjects exposed to plant glyco-epitopes, including bromelain. Some developed transient IgG and IgE responses, but these returned to baseline within 6 months without clinical symptoms.
population_specificity: 280 subjects (including 40 with pre-existing plant allergies) enrolled in Phase I/II trials.
effective_dosage: Not specified for bromelain (study focused on 5-45 μg of HA/dose for vaccines).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of oral bromelain versus diclofenac sodium on pain, swelling, trismus, and quality of life after surgical removal of impacted lower third molars.
results_summary: Bromelain significantly reduced pain compared to placebo, with effects comparable to diclofenac, but showed insignificant reduction in swelling and nonsignificant reduction in trismus. Both bromelain and diclofenac significantly improved quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients requiring extraction of a single partial bony impacted mandibular third molar under local anesthesia.
study_duration: 5 days (1 day pre-surgery and 4 days post-surgery)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bromelain affects selectin-mediated leukocyte rolling, specifically its impact on P-selectin and E-selectin binding in human neutrophils.
results_summary: Bromelain treatment reduced P-selectin-mediated tethering of human neutrophils but had no effect on E-selectin binding. It selectively cleaved PSGL-1, removing a site required for P-selectin binding while leaving the E-selectin binding region intact.
population_specificity: Human neutrophils

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and analgesic effects of orally administered Bromelain in patients recovering from impacted lower molar extraction.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences between Bromelain and placebo groups, though a non-significant trend suggested reduced inflammation and improved oral aperture with Bromelain. The authors concluded that further research is needed to assess different dosages and administration patterns.
population_specificity: 34 patients undergoing postoperative recovery from impacted lower molar extraction.
effective_dosage: 150mg per day for three days, then 100mg per day for days 4-7.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy, tolerability, and impact on quality of life of bromelain tablets (500 FIP) in patients with chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS).
results_summary: Bromelain improved symptom scores, rhinoscopy scores, and quality of life, with greater efficacy observed in CRS without nasal polyps (CRS-NP) than in CRS with nasal polyps (CRS+NP). No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: 12 patients with CRS (with or without nasal polyps) who had prior sinus surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of commercial and recombinant bromelain on MCF-7 breast cancer cells to evaluate their potential as therapeutic alternatives in cancer treatment.
results_summary: Both commercial and recombinant bromelain significantly reduced MCF-7 cell viability, with IC50 values of 5.13 μg/mL and 6.25 μg/mL, respectively, and demonstrated anti-proliferative activity similar to taxol. Microscopic observations confirmed cell detachment and dynamic growth rate reductions.
population_specificity: MCF-7 breast cancer cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether drinking pineapple juice (containing Bromelain) could effectively dissolve undigested food remnants in the stomach before endoscopic removal of intragastric balloons.
results_summary: The study found that drinking 1 L of pineapple juice daily for 3 days before the procedure eliminated undigested food remnants in all patients, compared to significant remnants observed without pineapple juice.
population_specificity: 19 obese patients (17 female, 2 male) with a mean BMI of 49.73 kg/m² undergoing endoscopic removal of intragastric balloons.
effective_dosage: 1 liter of 100% pineapple juice per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enzymatic debridement with NexoBrid™ (NXB) could reduce the need for surgery while achieving similar esthetic and functional outcomes as standard of care (SOC) in deep burns.
results_summary: NXB significantly reduced time to complete debridement, need for surgery, area of burns excised, and need for autografting compared to SOC, while achieving similar scar quality, quality of life scores, and adverse event rates.
population_specificity: Patients aged 4-55 years with deep partial and full thickness burns covering 5-30% of their total body surface area (TBSA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical relevance of a complex containing Bromelain, Devil's claw, and turmeric in treating degenerative joint pain, assessing its efficacy and safety.
results_summary: The study found that the Bromelain-containing complex significantly reduced pain scores in both acute and chronic osteoarthritis patients, meeting clinically meaningful improvement thresholds, with no reported adverse effects leading to withdrawal.
population_specificity: 42 patients (36 women; mean age 67 years) with acute or chronic degenerative spine or joint pain.
effective_dosage: Two 650 mg capsules of AINAT (containing Bromelain) 3 times daily for acute pain and 2 times daily for chronic pain.
study_duration: 15 days for acute pain group, 60 days for chronic pain group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a supplement containing bromelain, among other components, could improve tendon healing and reduce pain after rotator cuff repair surgery.
results_summary: The supplement group showed significantly lower shoulder pain at 6 months and better repair integrity at final follow-up compared to the control group, though functional outcomes did not differ significantly.
population_specificity: 90 patients with large, postero-superior rotator cuff tears undergoing arthroscopic repair.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential anticancer properties of bromelain, particularly its effects on MUC1-expressing cancer cells and its ability to enhance the efficacy of chemotherapeutic drugs like cisplatin and 5-FU.
results_summary: Bromelain adversely affected the viability of MUC1-expressing pancreatic, breast, and malignant peritoneal mesothelioma (MPM) cancer cells and enhanced the efficacy of cisplatin and 5-FU, suggesting it may disrupt MUC1's barrier function. The study also noted increased accumulation of 5-FU in cells when combined with bromelain.
population_specificity: MUC1-expressing cancer cells (pancreatic, breast, and malignant peritoneal mesothelioma).
interactions: Enhanced efficacy of cisplatin and 5-FU when used adjuvantly with bromelain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining dietary supplements (including bromelain) with extracorporeal shockwave therapy (ESWT) improves outcomes in insertional Achilles tendinopathy compared to ESWT alone.
results_summary: The study found that the experimental group (receiving dietary supplements including bromelain) showed significantly better outcomes at 6 months in pain reduction (VAS), functional improvement (Ankle-Hindfoot Scale), and patient satisfaction (Roles and Maudsley score) compared to the placebo group. Tissue oximetry values also improved significantly in the experimental group by 6 months.
population_specificity: Patients with insertional Achilles tendinopathy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (daily dietary supplement containing bromelain among other ingredients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of bromelain on inflammation-related cytokines and its immunomodulatory potential in humans.
results_summary: Bromelain 3000 FIP units significantly altered the circadian profile of IFNγ and showed trends in modulating IL-5 and IL-10, suggesting an effect on the T cell compartment of the immune system. This is the first evidence of bromelain modulating lymphocyte responses after oral administration.
population_specificity: Human participants in a randomized clinical trial (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Single dose (duration of follow-up not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of bromelain in controlling edema and related pain after upper third molar extraction.
results_summary: The study demonstrated bromelain's effectiveness in reducing postoperative edema and pain following third molar surgery, as measured by facial profile assessments and pain scales.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing upper third molar exodontia.

study_goal: To assess the in vitro stain removal efficacy of a novel dentifrice containing Bromelain compared to a control.
results_summary: The test dentifrice showed significantly higher stain removal (66.99% ± 9.57) compared to the control (25.89% ± 16.2), with a statistically significant difference (P < 0.001). The mean lightness increment was also notably higher for the test group (13.7 ± 6.35) versus the control (3.16 ± 1.29).
population_specificity: Human molar teeth (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize existing data on bromelain's anti-cancer activity and suggest mechanisms for its effects based on non-cancer models.
results_summary: The study found that bromelain exhibits anti-inflammatory, anti-thrombotic, fibrinolytic, and anti-cancer functions, with evidence suggesting systemic action on multiple cellular and molecular targets. It may modulate key pathways supporting malignancy and impact cancer cells, their microenvironment, and immune/inflammatory systems.
population_specificity: Not specified (evidence derived from clinical observations, mouse- and cell-based models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Macuprev (a supplement containing Bromelain) on functional and structural changes in patients with intermediate age-related macular degeneration (AMD).
results_summary: The study found a significant increase in mfERG response amplitude density in central macular areas for the Macuprev group, but no significant changes in retinal or choroidal SD-OCT parameters. No significant differences were observed in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 30 patients with intermediate AMD, divided into two age-similar groups (mean age 68.50 ± 8.79 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute bromelain supplementation influenced markers of muscle damage and testosterone levels in competitive cyclists during a six-day stage race.
results_summary: Bromelain supplementation reduced subjective fatigue and showed a trend toward maintaining testosterone levels, though markers of muscle damage increased similarly in both groups. No significant adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Fifteen highly trained male competitive cyclists (average age 22 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with bromelain (combined with rutoside and trypsin) could reduce post-marathon inflammation and upper respiratory illness incidence in male runners.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in inflammatory markers (IL-6, IL-10, CRP, leukocytes) or URI incidence between the supplemented and placebo groups, indicating bromelain did not attenuate inflammation or reduce illness rates.
population_specificity: Healthy male marathon runners (N = 138, age 42 ± 11 years).
effective_dosage: 540-1080 mg/day bromelain (combined with 600-1200 mg/day rutoside and 288-576 mg/day trypsin).
study_duration: 1 week before and 2 weeks after the marathon (3 weeks total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different salinity levels and germination periods on momilactone and phenolic accumulations in germinated brown rice (GBR) var. Koshihikari.
results_summary: GBR treated with 75 mM salinity for 4 days (B2 treatment) showed the highest levels of bioactive compounds (momilactones, phenolic acids, and flavonoids) and the strongest antiradical activities in DPPH and ABTS assays. These findings suggest potential health benefits of GBR consumption.
population_specificity: Germinated brown rice (var. Koshihikari) under controlled salinity and germination conditions.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on salinity levels and germination periods rather than human dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of heat moisture treatment (HMT), extrusion treatment (ET), and their combination (HMT-ET) on the microstructural, physicochemical properties, and starch digestibility of brown rice flour (BRF).
results_summary: The study found that HMT-ET BRF showed a significant reduction in expected glycemic index (eGI), increased resistant starch (RS), and improved physicochemical properties compared to HMT or ET alone. The combination treatment also induced starch gelatinization and inhibited retrogradation, suggesting enhanced digestibility and functional properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on brown rice flour)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the organic matter release capacity and economic viability of brown rice as a solid carbon source (SCS) for low-carbon wastewater treatment.
results_summary: Brown rice demonstrated high COD release potential (309.2 mg-COD/g-SCS), rapid release rate (581.3 mg-COD/L·d), and maximum accumulation (6183.3 mg-COD/L). Activated sludge addition enhanced organic matter release, increasing VFAs proportion to 97.1% and improving carbon utilization rate to 45.4% in 12 days.
population_specificity: Not applicable (laboratory study on wastewater treatment).
effective_dosage: Not specified (measured in COD release per gram of SCS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ascorbic acid treatment, alone or combined with degreasing or hydrothermal treatment, could improve the eating quality and in vitro digestibility of brown rice.
results_summary: The study found that degreasing combined with ascorbic acid hydrothermal treatment significantly improved the texture, sensory score, and in vitro digestibility of brown rice, reducing hardness and chewiness while increasing stickiness and water uptake. The treatment also reduced relative crystallinity and water contact angle, enhancing starch granule separation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether foliar application of selenium (Se) could enhance the nutritional value of brown rice without compromising quality.
results_summary: Selenium biofortification significantly increased Se levels in brown rice grains (up to 17.06 µg g-1 in Ariete and 14.28 µg g-1 in Ceres), affected K and P contents, and increased protein content in Ariete but not Ceres. No significant differences were noted for most other elements except Ca, where Se appeared to antagonize uptake.
population_specificity: Ariete and Ceres rice varieties grown in experimental fields.
effective_dosage: First foliar application: 500 g Se·ha-1; subsequent applications: 300 g Se·ha-1 (applied at booting, anthesis, and milky grain stages).
study_duration: Not explicitly stated, but interventions were applied at three developmental stages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-hypertensive effects of parboiled germinated brown rice (PGBR) by examining its impact on the renin-angiotensin system, fibrosis, oxidative stress, and cardiac structure in hypertensive rats.
results_summary: PGBR significantly reduced systolic blood pressure, suppressed key hypertension-related genes (AT1R, TGF-β, NOX4), and improved cardiac lesions in hypertensive rats, with effects comparable to the anti-hypertensive drug Losartan. White rice did not show similar benefits due to loss of bioactive compounds during milling.
population_specificity: L-NAME-induced hypertensive rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of bromelain as a nutritional supplement for managing risk factors associated with cardiovascular diseases (CVDs).
results_summary: Bromelain showed potential benefits in reducing blood platelet aggregation, providing cardio-protective effects, ameliorating arterial wall remodelling, preventing thrombin-induced platelet aggregation, and reducing thrombus formation. However, no substantive human clinical trials were identified.
population_specificity: Animal and human trials (3 each), but no specific human population details provided.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Sinlek rice (a type of brown rice) consumption affects gut microbiota composition and cognitive function in school-aged children.
results_summary: Sinlek rice consumption did not significantly alter gut microbiota abundance or cognitive performance in children, but age was associated with variations in both gut microbiota profiles and cognitive outcomes.
population_specificity: 127 school-aged children in northern Thailand
study_duration: Weeks 4 and 61 (middle time points mentioned, exact total duration unclear)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the influence of a germinated brown rice (GBR) diet on type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) patients over 3 months and whether this effect relates to changes in serum fatty acids.
results_summary: The GBR intervention reduced dietary inflammation index (DII), improved glycolipid parameters (FBG, HbA1c, TC, HDL), and altered fatty acid composition, increasing n-3 PUFA and n-3/n-6 PUFA ratios. It also elevated anti-inflammatory n-3 metabolites (RVE, MaR1, PD1) and reduced pro-inflammatory n-6 metabolites (LTB4, PGE2).
population_specificity: 112 T2DM patients (61 female, 51 male), with final analysis on 42 in the GBR group and 43 in the control group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how cannabis impacts gut microbiome, immune function, and antiretroviral therapy (ART) outcomes in people with HIV (PWH), focusing on its potential to reduce inflammation and improve gut health.
results_summary: Cannabis demonstrated immunomodulatory and anti-inflammatory effects, including reduced systemic inflammatory biomarkers, improved gut barrier integrity, and increased gut mucosal immunity. Preliminary evidence suggests it may influence HIV reservoirs, though results remain inconclusive.
population_specificity: People with HIV (PWH)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of medical cannabis as an adjunctive therapy for moderate PTSD under varying reimbursement scenarios.
results_summary: Non-flower medical cannabis products (edibles, oral solutions, and tablets) were consistently cost-effective under a $50,000 willingness-to-pay threshold, even at full reimbursement. Dried flower products were less cost-effective but achieved cost-effectiveness at lower reimbursement levels for low/moderate-cost formulations.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).
